channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iran Races to Clinch Oil Deals Before Donald Trump Takes Office
item.media:description: A refinery south of Tehran. Iran has looked abroad for the expertise and capital it needs to expand oil production.
item.description: Worried about the American president-elect’s rhetoric, Tehran has signed a wave of agreements since Nov. 8 with European and Asian energy companies.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Facebook Struggles to Put Out Online Fires in Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
item.media:description: Israeli firefighters trying to extinguish a blaze last month in Nataf, near Jerusalem. When recent fires erupted, some Palestinians celebrated on social media.
item.description: Israel has pushed to combat online provocation that it links to bloodshed, while Palestinians consider a crackdown on posts just another tool of repression.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Girl Posting to Twitter From Aleppo Gains Sympathy, but Doubts Follow
item.description: Bana al-Abed, 7, has more than 220,000 followers on Twitter, where she chronicles the deprivations of a child in war-torn Syria. But she has also raised questions of authenticity.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE, MEGAN SPECIA and SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: After a Cyberattack, Germany Fears Election Disruption
item.media:description: The Deutsche Telekom headquarters in Bonn, Germany. A recent disruption of its services set off alarm about the vulnerability of Germany’s computer networks
item.description: An attack on Deutsche Telekom has Berlin concerned about becoming a target of Moscow’s campaign to destabilize Western democracies.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Boris Johnson Lashes Out at Saudi Arabia and Gets Stung at Home
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, Britain’s foreign secretary, had accused Saudi Arabia, a British ally, of “puppeteering” in “proxy wars” across the Middle East and of “abusing Islam.”
item.description: He had accused the country, a British ally, of “puppeteering” in “proxy wars” across the Middle East and of “abusing Islam,” and he received an upbraiding from Prime Minister Theresa May.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Cuba’s Surge in Tourism Keeps Food Off Residents’ Plates
item.media:description: Workers in a lettuce field this past week at a farm in Alamar, outside Havana.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Consumption by visitors — nearly 3.5 million last year — is overwhelming supplies and raising prices, forcing families to make do with even less than usual.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Canada Wonders, if U.S. Balks, Is Carbon Pricing Still the Answer
item.media:description: A cement plant in Richmond, British Columbia. The Canadian government is pushing a national plan to reduce emissions.
item.description: Donald J. Trump’s stance on climate change has ignited a debate over a plan by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to reduce carbon emissions by putting a price on them.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

item.title: U.S. Marine Pilot Dies After Ejecting From Plane Off Japan
item.description: A U.S. Marine pilot has died after he ejected from his FA-18C+ fighter jet as the aircraft went down off the coast of Japan, the U.S. military said in a statement on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Carter Page, Ex-Trump Adviser With Russian Ties, Visits Moscow
item.media:description: Carter Page in Moscow in July.
item.description: Mr. Page, who was scrutinized by the F.B.I. on suspicion of private communications with senior Russian officials last summer, said he would meet with “business leaders and thought leaders.”
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: U.N. Says Nearly One in Four Children Live in Conflict or Disaster Zones
item.description: About 535 million children worldwide now live in countries destabilized by conflicts and calamities, Unicef announced.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: ISIS Remains Threat in Libya Despite Defeat in Surt, U.S. Officials Say
item.media:description: Forces aligned with the United Nations-backed unity government in Surt, Libya, in June. Libyan forces drove the Islamic State out of the city this week.
item.description: Officials say surviving fighters could go underground and exploit the economic and political vacuum, threatening not only the country but also its neighbors and possibly Europe.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: Who Haunts U.K. Ghost Trains? Railway Enthusiasts
item.media:description: Why do “ghost trains” operate? Believe it or not, it’s a money-saving strategy for railroad companies in Britain.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lena Bush; Photo by Antonio Mingot
item.description: The trains, bureaucratic curiosities that run infrequently and visit forgotten stations, are a draw for railroad fans, who try to ride as many as possible.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: Danish Doctors’ Group Wants to End Circumcision for Boys
item.media:description: After a circumcision ceremony in Brooklyn in 2014.
item.media:credit: Michael Nagle for The New York Times
item.description: The medical association in Denmark said the procedure should be an “informed personal choice” that men make for themselves when they reach adulthood.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: Trilobites: That Thing With Feathers Trapped in Amber? It Was a Dinosaur Tail
item.media:description: A 99-million-year-old piece of amber with a feathered dinosaur tail trapped inside.
item.description: A Chinese paleontologist’s discovery in an amber market is offering new insights into the evolution of feathers.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Killing of I.R.A. Splinter Group Figure Rattles Irish City
item.description: The killing of Aidan O’Driscoll, known as “the Beast,” in the southwest city of Cork was the first gangland-style execution in Ireland in four years.
item.dc:creator: SINEAD O’SHEA

item.title: Giraffes, Towering and Otherworldly, Are ‘Vulnerable’ to Extinction
item.media:description: A giraffe in Amboseli National park, Kenya, in August.
item.description: The population of the world’s tallest land mammal has dropped by 40 percent in three decades, a report said.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK HEALY
item.category: International Union for the Conservation of Nature

item.title: Former French Official Convicted of Tax Fraud
item.media:description: Jérôme Cahuzac, a former French budget minister, leaving court in Paris on Thursday after being sentenced to three years in prison for tax fraud and money laundering.
item.description: A prison sentence for Jérôme Cahuzac is an embarrassment for the troubled administration of President François Hollande, who has said he will not run for re-election.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Muslim Women in Hijab Break Barriers: ‘Take the Good With the Bad’
item.media:description: Ginella Massa, 29, a TV reporter for CityNews in Toronto, is believed to be Canada’s first anchor to wear a hijab at one of the city’s major news broadcasters.
item.description: Even as reports of hate crimes against Muslims rise in America and Canada, hijabis are appearing in makeup ads, beauty pageants and news anchor chairs.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Soveria Mannelli Journal: Digitizing an Old-World Work Ethic, and Reaping the Rewards
item.media:description: Mario Caligiuri, the longtime mayor of Soveria Mannelli, Italy, who is now a university professor, in his studio last month.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: How the internet helped save a small Calabrian town by becoming a lifeline for family businesses.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Hundreds of U.K. Police Officers Said to Have Sexually Abused Vulnerable People
item.media:description: Officers in London. A report found that there had been 436 accusations of police sexual abuse in England and Wales over the two years ending in March.
item.description: A report by a national watchdog found that domestic abuse victims, drug and alcohol addicts and people who work in the sex industry had been targeted.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: E.U. Threatens to Sue 4 Countries Where VW Sold Polluting Cars
item.media:description: Volkswagen cars inside a delivery tower in Wolfsburg, Germany, in April.
item.description: The move against Britain, Germany, Luxembourg and Spain is an apparent attempt to catch up after facing criticism for a lax response to a yearlong scandal.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and JACK EWING

item.title: Claims Against South Korean President: Extortion, Abuse of Power and Bribery
item.media:description: A protest in Seoul, South Korea, on Saturday calling for President Park Geun-hye to step down.
item.description: Ahead of Friday’s impeachment vote, here are the accusations against President Park Geun-hye, which she has dismissed as a “house of cards.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Defiance and Disillusionment in Heartland of South Korean President’s Support
item.media:description: In what appeared to be a last-ditch effort to court her remaining supporters, President Park Geun-hye visited Daegu, South Korea, last week, making a rare public appearance after a fire destroyed part of a market.
item.description: Unlike the vast majority of South Koreans, some in Daegu, a city where President Park Geun-hye has deep political roots, see her as an innocent victim of a scandal.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: South Korea’s President Awaits Her Fate, Dejected, Sleepless and Alone
item.media:description: About 1.7 million people protested in central Seoul on Saturday, calling for Ms. Park to step down.
item.description: As her presidency crumbles, Park Geun-hye has been cloistered in the presidential palace and is rarely seen in public.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: E.C.B. Extends Bond-Buying Program to Protect Eurozone Economy
item.description: The European Central Bank also said it would cut the size of the program next year, while insisting it had no plans to end asset purchases altogether.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Malta Outlaws ‘Conversion Therapy,’ a First in Europe
item.media:description: The Palace in Saint George’s Square in Valletta, Malta, in 2014. The country has been praised for its record on gay and transgender rights.
item.description: The Mediterranean island nation criminalized therapeutic methods that purport to change a person’s sexual orientation or gender identity, officials said.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: In Compromise, Brazil’s Supreme Court Allows Senate Leader to Stay
item.media:description: Brazil’s Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an order by one of its justices to suspend Renan Calheiros, the president of the Senate.
item.description: The court ended a tense standoff between the judiciary and Congress when it rejected an order by one of its justices to remove Renan Calheiros from his post.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Nguyen Ngoc Luong, Times Guide in Vietnam War, Dies at 79
item.media:description: A reporter from Stars and Stripes helped a wounded Nguyen Ngoc Luong to flee mortar fire on April 6, 1972.
item.description: Mr. Luong’s small credits on photographs belied his other vital but unheralded journalistic contributions in bringing home the brutality of the war.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Bolivia Detains Chief of Airline in Colombia Crash
item.description: Investigators also seized files from the airline in a widening inquiry into the crash in Colombia of a jet carrying the Brazilian soccer team Chapecoense.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and MONICA MACHICAO

item.title: Rio Proposal: Tax Tourists to Help Them When They Are Mugged
item.media:description: The beach at Ipanema, popular among foreign visitors and natives of Rio de Janeiro alike.
item.description: The mayor-elect, Marcelo Crivella, is promoting the new idea as a way to bolster tourism in the crime-plagued city.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Torture Is ‘Common Practice’ in Sri Lanka, U.N. Panel Finds
item.description: The Committee on Torture also pointed to a failure to rapidly investigate and prosecute atrocities committed at the end of the country’s 26-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Matteo Renzi Resigns, Ending Italy’s 63rd Government in 70 Years
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy in Rome on Monday.
item.description: Mr. Renzi stepped down as prime minister three days after constitutional changes on which he had staked his political career were rejected by voters.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Crackdown in Turkey Threatens a Haven of Gender Equality Built by Kurds
item.media:description: Graffiti in Diyarbakir, Turkey, in support of the pro-Kurdish H.D.P. party, which has won 50 seats in Turkey’s Parliament and endured a government crackdown.
item.description: Kurdish society’s longstanding commitment to equal rights for women is under attack in the face of Turkey’s crackdown after a failed coup attempt.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Muslim Separatist Militants in Thailand Kill 6 Civilians
item.description: The violence, which occurred in six separate episodes over 24 hours, may have been retribution for the arrest of militants, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: How Pearl Harbor Shaped the Modern World
item.media:description: A memorial facility was built over the U.S.S. Arizona, a battleship that was attacked at Pearl Harbor.
item.description: Seventy-five years after the attack drew the United States into World War II, an abiding memory is fading.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Tiny Snail Defeats Donald Trump in Battle Over Irish Sea Wall
item.media:description: Doughmore Bay, seen from a Trump Organization golf club near Doonbeg, Ireland.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect’s real estate organization has abandoned plans to build a long barrier off the west coast of Ireland to protect its golf course there.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM and SINEAD O’SHEA

item.title: WikiLeaks Founder Julian Assange Denies Rape in Detailed Account of Encounter
item.media:description: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange at the balcony of the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February.
item.description: Mr. Assange released the answers to questions prepared by Swedish prosecutors, and in his replies he also railed against Sweden and Britain, saying he had been “arbitrarily detained.”
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Camilo Cienfuegos Journal: In Cuban Town That Hershey Built, Memories Both Bitter and Sweet
item.media:description: The Camilo Cienfuegos train station in Cuba, where Hershey signs still hang in a nod to a bygone era, when the town produced sugar for Milton S. Hershey, the American chocolate baron.
item.media:credit: Lisette Poole for The New York Times
item.description: A sugar-refinery village founded a century ago by the American chocolate baron has since lost much of its luster. But local pride lingers.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Sinosphere: China Pushes Back on Michael Flynn’s ‘Radical Islamist’ Remarks
item.media:description: Retired Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, the choice of President-elect Donald J. Trump for national security adviser, speaking at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in July.
item.description: A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman addressed assertions by Mr. Flynn, picked to be America’s next national security adviser, that China was allied with jihadists.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Pakistan Passenger Plane Crashes With 48 on Board
item.description: At least 40 bodies have been recovered from the Pakistani International Airlines crash. Junaid Jamshed, a famous former pop singer, was among those on board.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: In Rebel-Held Aleppo, Residents Report Increasing Desperation
item.media:description: A view of Aleppo, Syria, on Wednesday showed smoke rising after shelling on neighborhoods in the Old City.
item.description: Antigovernment activists in the city were sending increasingly desperate messages about being killed or arrested, and civilians called for safe passage out.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Indonesia Earthquake Kills More Than 100 in Aceh Province
item.media:description: Rescuers looked for survivors amid the rubble on Wednesday in Lueng Putu, Indonesia, after an undersea earthquake struck Aceh province.
item.description: The temblor had a preliminary magnitude of 6.5 and struck while many were asleep.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Sinosphere: How Trump’s Call With Taiwan Could Affect U.S. Goals in Asia
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump in Cincinnati last week. Mr. Trump’s call with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan shattered decades of diplomatic protocol and raised questions about his strategy toward China.
item.description: Paul Haenle, a retired Army officer who served on the National Security Council, gauges the consequences of the president-elect’s action.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Making South Africa Great Again
item.media:description: An anti-government march in Pretoria, South Africa, last month.
item.description: As in America, ‘exceptionalism’ can create dangerous myths about a country. But it can also inspire a powerful reform movement.
item.dc:creator: SISONKE MSIMANG

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Bumpy Peace for Colombia
item.media:description: A rally in support of the peace process, a few blocks from where a revised agreement was being signed, in Bogotá, Colombia, last month.
item.description: The FARC is on the way to disappearing as an insurgent armed force, but peace is still uncertain.
item.dc:creator: MARTA RUIZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Ghosts Spain Tries to Ignore
item.description: The country of Franco has yet to reconcile with its violent past. As fascism is on the march across Europe, will that finally change?
item.dc:creator: DAN HANCOX
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
